extends java.lang.Object
    Test case for Market

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void Contractor()
      Reset market to its default status.
      void marketCanCheckResourceMoreThanAmountYouWantToBuy()
      test: hasEnoughResources player class can use this method to find out that the amount of resource player want to buy is available in the market, if the amount of resource in the market is less than the amount of resources player want to buy then throw exception
      void marketShouldAbleToGetAndSetResources()
      test setEnergy(), setOre(), setFood(), setRoboticon() The market should be able to set and get resources.
      void marketShouldHaveCorrectPricesForResources()
      test: getBuyPrice() The market should start with correct price for player to buy.
      void marketShouldInitWithCorrectValues()
      The market should start with correct amount of resources.
      void marketShouldReduceResourcesWhenSells()
      Tests Market.sellResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that resources are actually removed from the market
      void marketShouldReturnCorrectSellPrice()
      test: getSellPrice()
      void setEnergyNegativeValue()
      Tests Market.setEnergy(int) ensures that an exception is thrown when a negative value is passed to it
      void setFoodNegativeValue()
      Tests Market.setFood(int) ensures that an exception is thrown when a negative value is passed to it
      void setOreNegativeValue()
      Tests Market.setOre(int) ensures that an exception is thrown when a negative value is passed to it
      void setRoboticonNegativeValue()
      Tests Market.setRoboticon(int) ensures that an exception is thrown when a negative value is passed to it
      void testAttemptToProduceRoboticonNoOreRemoved()
      Tests Market.attemptToProduceRoboticon() ensures that no ore is removed from the market (when the market does not have enough ore to produce a roboticon)
      void testAttemptToProduceRoboticonNoRoboticonAdded()
      Tests Market.attemptToProduceRoboticon() ensures that no roboticons are added to the market when the market does have enough ore
      void testAttemptToProduceRoboticonOreRemoved()
      Tests Market.attemptToProduceRoboticon() ensures that the correct amount of ore is removed from the market
      void testAttemptToProduceRoboticonReturnFalse()
      Tests Market.attemptToProduceRoboticon() ensures that it returns false when the market does have enough ore
      void testAttemptToProduceRoboticonReturnTrue()
      Tests Market.attemptToProduceRoboticon() ensures that it returns true when the market has enough ore
      void testAttemptToProduceRoboticonRoboticonAdded()
      Tests Market.attemptToProduceRoboticon() ensures that one roboticon is added to the market when the market has enough ore
      void testBuyFiveEnergy()
      Tests Market.buyResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that five energy are added to the market when called with ResourceType.ENERGY and 5 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed
      void testBuyFourFood()
      Tests Market.buyResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that four food are added to the market when called with ResourceType.FOOD and 4 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed
      void testBuyOneEnergy()
      Tests Market.buyResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that one energy is added to the market when called with ResourceType.ENERGY and 1 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed
      void testBuyOneFood()
      Tests Market.buyResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that one food is added to the market when called with ResourceType.FOOD and 1 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed
      void testBuyOneOre()
      Tests Market.buyResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that one ore is added to the market when called with ResourceType.ORE and 1 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed
      void testBuyThreeOre()
      Tests Market.buyResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that three ore are added to the market when called with ResourceType.ORE and 3 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed
      void testSellFiveEnergy()
      Tests Market.sellResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that five energy are removed from the market when called with ResourceType.ENERGY and 5 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed
      void testSellFourFood()
      Tests Market.sellResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that four food are removed from the market when called with ResourceType.FOOD and 4 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed
      void testSellOneEnergy()
      Tests Market.sellResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that one energy is removed from the market when called with ResourceType.ENERGY and 1 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed

      Tests Market.sellResource(ResourceType, int) ensures that one food is removed from the market when called with ResourceType.FOOD and 1 as it is simply a wrapper for setResource only a few simple tests are needed

      • marketShouldInitWithCorrectValues

        public void marketShouldInitWithCorrectValues()
        The market should start with correct amount of resources. 16 Food and Energy, 0 Ore, 12 Robotics

      • marketShouldAbleToGetAndSetResources

        public void marketShouldAbleToGetAndSetResources()
        test setEnergy(), setOre(), setFood(), setRoboticon() The market should be able to set and get resources.

      • marketShouldHaveCorrectPricesForResources

        public void marketShouldHaveCorrectPricesForResources()
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        test: getBuyPrice() The market should start with correct price for player to buy. The price is 90% of the sell price. This could change in later development.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • marketCanCheckResourceMoreThanAmountYouWantToBuy

        public void marketCanCheckResourceMoreThanAmountYouWantToBuy()
        test: hasEnoughResources player class can use this method to find out that the amount of resource player want to buy is available in the market, if the amount of resource in the market is less than the amount of resources player want to buy then throw exception
